Package com.analog.lyric.options

Statically typed hierarchical option support.

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    IOption<T extends java.io.Serializable>
    An immutable option key value pair.
    IOptionConfigurable
    Interface for non-option-holder objects that can be configured using options.
    IOptionHolder
    Interface for object that can hold option values.
    IOptionKey<T extends java.io.Serializable>
    A unique key for looking up or setting a value from a IOptionHolder.
    IOptionValue
    Base interface for non-primitive option values.

    Key for boolean options.

    Key for options with literal Java class values.

    Key for options with literal Java class values with accessible no-argument constructor.

    Key for options with list of double values.

    Key for double options.

    Key for options holding a pair of double values that define a range.

    Option key for an enumerated type.

    A generic IOptionKey implementation.

    Key for options with list of integer values.

    Option key with type Integer.

    Provides standard implementation of IOptionHolder methods.

    Represents list of doubles for use as option value.

    Represents list of integers for use as option value.

    Base implementation of IOptionKey interface.

    Base for classes that declare option keys.

    An immutable map of option keys declared in a single class.
    OptionParentIterator
    Iterates chain of option parents.
    OptionRegistry
    A registry of known option keys indexed by qualified name.

    Represents list of doubles for use as option value.

    Provides a minimal stateless implementation of IOptionHolder methods.

Package com.analog.lyric.options Description

Statically typed hierarchical option support.

This package provides a type-safe framework for getting/setting simple option settings in a hierarchical fashion.

Options are indexed by instances of the IOptionKey interface that are declared as public static final fields of some publicly accessible class. Typically such classes will contain nothing other than option declarations and will make use of the concrete subclasses of OptionKey provided by this package. Note that the option key interface allows you to specify default values for options for use when the option has not been explicitly set. It is also useful to organize these classes in a hierarchical fashion inheriting from OptionKeyDeclarer. This allows Java IDE users to easily visualize available options in the class hierarchy viewer. Here is a simple example: 

 public class GuiOptions extends OptionKeyDeclarer
 {
     /**
      * Document your option here
      */
     public final StringOptionKey color =
         new StringOptionKey(MyOptions.class, "color", "white");
 }

Sometimes when an option only applies to a single class, it may be easier to define the option key in that class directly rather than in a separately defined option declaration class.

Classes that support getting and setting options must implement the IOptionHolder interface and will typically extend LocalOptionHolder, which provides the ability to store options locally in the object.

Options can be get or set using the corresponding key with an option holder and can be done either through methods on the key or the holder. Here are two equivalent ways to set a color option on a widget object: 

     if (GuiOptions.color.get(widget).equals("blue"))
     {
         GuiOptions.color.set(widget, "red");
     }
 
     if (widget.getOption(GuiOptions.color).equals("blue"))
     {
         widget.setOption(GuiOptions.color, "red");
     }

Some option key classes may support additional variants of the set method to automatically combine or convert arguments, which may make is desirable to set the option through the key's method rather than setOption. For instance, the StringListOptionKey class overloads the set method to directly take strings as arguments: 

     // Shorter version using key-specific set method:
     MyOptions.names.set(widget, "foo", "bar", "baz");
 
     // Longer version using generic setOption method:
     widget.setOption(MyOptions.names, new OptionStringList("foo", "bar", baz"));

If you want an object to inherit option values from an other object in a hierarchical fashion, you can implement the getOptionParent() method to indicate the default provider for option values. For instance, in a GUI framework you might want components to inherit attributes such as background color or font size from elements they are contained in. You can also implement more sophisticated inheritance schemes by overriding getOptionDelegates().
